text: Seen from above: JESUS, the son of Mary, 28 years-old, es on a scrubby hillock under an olive tree. The mid-morning sun shines on his clean-shaven face. He is dreaming:

The pain starts just above the neck. It feels as if an old man has snuck up and grabbed me from behind. His fingers slip underneath the skin and work, claw, their way up the back of my neck. Then the real pain begins. Each finger digs into the soft matter behind my brain, and then strain across the top of my head toward my eyes. Just before they reach the eyes, they dig down... Jesus wakens. He looks around, holding his head.
(continuing) I remembered I had to make a cross.

Jesus shapes a long piece of timber with an adze. His patched tunic rests on the workbench. The white plaster-and-brick walls are hung with the tools of Jesus’ trade: saws, hammers, rasps and measuring squares. Two small windows let in light and breeze from the village. His face is etched by lines caused by thinking too much. Brain fever. A nail-studded belt hangs from a hook above his head. The belt is speckled with dried blood.

4c first I fasted for three months. Then I whipped myself before sleeping. At first it worked, then the headaches returned. Jesus wipes wood shavings from his sweaty chest. He hears a NOISE from outside. Frightened, he looks toward t jOor: (CONTINUED)

(continuing) Who is it? Who are you? Why are you following me? JUDAS, 30, blacksmith, bursts into the room. The door RATTLES on its wood hinges. Jesus goes back to work. Judas' face is ablaze with wild red hair, beard and moustache. His bulging forearms are dirtied by grease, burnt by fire. He belongs to the Sicarri ("assassins") the terrorist wing of,the Zealots, a radical Jewish po- litical organization. His presence is frightening.

I thought I'd find you here. Aren't you ashamed? The carpenters from Cana and Capernaum refuse to make a cross for a Zealot, but you get up and throw yourself into it like a madman. Where's your pride? Jesus, silent, backs away.
(continuing) What if the Messiah were to come now and find you doing this? Jesus returns to his adze. He says quietly:
Leave me alone, Judas. I mst work.
Aren't you ashamed?
(softly) No.
You've seen them hanging there for days, skin falling off their bodies. Crying night after night. Our prophets. Because of the Romans and men like you. A migrain moves across Jesus' face. He winces:
No, I don't have any pride. I don't go to Synagogue. I disobey the commandments. I work on the Sabbath. (CONTINUED)
And who will pay for your sins?
I don't know. I'm struggling. Judas, disgusted, calls to the crowd outside.
Come here! Look at the traitor! Look at the cross-maker. The crowd jeers. Jesus resumes his task.

A CENTURION pushes his way through the crowds gathered outside the white-washed buildings. He is sickened by the foul-smelling Jewry. Jesus stands outside his workshop hewing a cyprus cross. A semi-circle of spiteful Israelites surrounds hin, The Centurion approaches:

You ready? (as Jesus nods) Com’ on. Jesus takes the nail-studded belt from its hook and buckles it around his waist. The Centurion helps Jesus heft the cross-beam to his shoulders. The Centurion leads Jesus through a gauntlet the crowd has formes from the village to a rocky hill outside Nazareth. Ahead, six Roman soldiers lead the protesting ZEALOT. Two mounted soldiers flank the group. The Zealot, crazed by fear, possessed by God, calls out to anyone who will listen:

Stand up Israelites! Now's the time of Judgement! Yahweh is counting everyone! Stand, be counted! The Zealot’s hands are tied behind him. His clothes are torn and bloody, his long hair and grey beard matted with blood and sweat. (CONTINUED)
Judas insinuates his way into a group of townspeople. Fearful of the Romans, he speaks wder his breath:

How long are we going take this? Can we let the Romans kill anyone who opens his mouth? When are we going be men? When will we. be Jews? No one pays attention to Judas. Seeing this, he with- draws . The villagers heap abuse on Jesus. PETER and JAMES are in the crowd. MARY, 56, mother of Jesus, pushes her way through the crowd. She stands in front of Jesus, trying to hold back the crowd with her arms. She calls out:

Forgive my son! He's crazy! He doesn't know what he's doing. He has problems. Ever since he was a baby. He's not well in the head. The crowd hoots her into silence. Jesus, turning his eyes from her, trudges forward. The CENTURION follows close behind. As they near the crucifixion site, another woman, MARY MAGDALENE, 25, approaches Jesus. She wears brightly colored clothes; her lips and cheeks are painted like a prostitute. The villagers revile her as she passes. She walks alongside Jesus, staring him in the face. The color flows from Jesus’ face: his resolve nearly melts with it.
Magdalene. Who told you to ceue?
You thought you could forget re. You never will. Jesus’ mind goes back to a day the previous year. Cut To:
A wedding feast in the lake village of Magdala. A long table is spread with fresh fruit, cheeses, bread and wine (CONTINUED)
MARY MAGDALENE'S FATHER proposes a toast:

Join me. A toast to the engagement of my first daughter, Mary, and Jesus of Nazareth. The celebrants raise their cups in a toast. Mary, Jesus' mother, beams. Away from the others, Jesus and Mary Magdalene speak.
I'll return. I promise.
I don't wnderstand.
I can't marry. God won't let me. He's pursuing me.
That's not God, it’s the devil. (holds his head) Jesus, you need a woman.
I must be alone. He comes at night into my head. God's angry with me. He pushes her away.
Are you serious? What about me? What will become of me? No one will have me. Jesus turns and walks away.
Magdalene spits in Jesus' face:
Cross~-maker! Jesus lowers his face. The Zealot's voice rings out: (CONTINUED)

Children, have faith in the God of Israel! Don't be afraid. Rome is in smoke. Remember the Maccabees, remember how they threw out the Greeks! In the same way we'll throw out the Romans! There is only one God of Hosts! The Zealot has reached the crucifixion site: a rocky, flint covered mound. The soldiers wait for the cross. Children throw pebbles at Jesus as he approaches the Zealot. The Roman guards brace themselves for violence. Jesus sets the cross down beside the Zealot. The guards wrestle the Zealot to the ground. Mary, unable to contain herself, bursts through the crowd:

Jesus! My son! Get away from here! The guards move toward her. Peter and ANOTHER MAN help the women take her away before the Romans can arrest her. Judas, sickened by this spectacle, walks away. The guards place the Zealot on the cross and tie his arms Jesus, moving the weges, readies the hole for the cross. The Magdalene throws herself at the Zealot's feet:

Be brave! One of the calvarymen drives her back with his horse. There will be no revolt today. The guards prepare to drive the nails into the Zealot's hands. A hush comes over the crowd. The spike is placed in the Zealot's palm. The hammer raised. Metal hits metal: the spike pierces the upraised hand. The Zealot's scream (almost ecstatic) is echoed by the cr Blood spatters; a drop falls on Jesus' lips.

Jesus, without staff or sandals, walks quickly across a grassy plain northeast of Nazareth. Although mich of the lake district" of Galilee is rocky and barren today, it was not so in Jesus' time. Then it was a fertile and pleasant valley, the treasure of the Mid-East. It was jater denuded -by the Turks. Behind Jesus, Nazareth stirs to life. Jesus leans his body into the wind as he reaches the cres of a low ridge:

If I take the goat's path south to bypass Magdala and Tiberias. Traders from East and West go out of gheir way to drink and whore and... Jesus watches a small caravan headed down the hills towar the sea. He shakes these thoughts from his mind.

(continuing) This is the happiest moment of my life. I've always felt something was after me. IT must be as stupid as everyone says. God only wanted me to join him in the desert. He waits in a well at the Monastery. Jesus skips for joy as he walks:
Why would he want somone as stunid as me? Thank you! He sings a psalm as he goes:

“The Lord reigns, let the earth be glad' let the distant shores rejoice. Rise up, O Judge of earth; pay back the proud what they deserve. How long will the wicked, 0 Lord, how, long will the wicked be jubilant?"

Jesus walks a hundred yards off the coast of the Sea of Gennesaret (today called Galilee). In the water a group of men pull in their nets after a morning of fishing. The are ZEBEDEE, James and John, PHILIP, a shepherd, stands w then, By American standards, the Sea of Gennesaret is quite sma 13 miles long and 8 miles wide. From any point, the oppo- site shore is visible. (CONTINUED)

To this day its sweet, clear water is naturally stocked with fish. Because it's located in a pocket in the hills, Gennesaret remains subject to sudden violent storms. On shore, Judas talks with Peter. Zebedee, fiftiesh, is the father of James and John. Peter spots Jesus and calls out:
Look who's here. Hey, Cross-maker! Jesus glances at them and keeps walking.
(calling out) You better keep walking. Don't stop here.

Don't bother him. We're all part of the same plan. The fish says, 'God, don't let me get caught,' The fisherman says, 'God, give me fish.' Back to work. (to Judas) Hey, Red! You mind your own business, too. Philip walks over to Peter and Judas and says to Zebedee:
Be careful, Zebedee. He's from the Idumea. Lions still live out there. Don't pick a fight with him. (to Judas) What's happening in the plain?
Everything's fine, Philip. The Lord's merciful. In Nazareth, He crucifies prophets. Here, He sends enough rain. to ruin a year's crops in one night. In Jerusalem, the Romans squat in the temple.
Shut up. Whatever God does is right.
It is for you. You hire fifty fishermen like slaves and pay them minimum. Then you give to the temple and get God's blessing.
Hey, you got the mark of Cain on you. Now get out! (CONTINUED)
Judas walks off, calling back to Zebedee:
I wouldn't want to be in your boat when the. Messiah comes. Philip catches up with him.
Wait. I want to talk to you.
Why now? Were you afraid a few minutes ago? The King of the Jews is on his way. Decide what side you are on.
Help me. I am afraid. But, I can't stand it anymore.
(moves close to him) Philip, can you kill?
A man?
What do you think? Sheep?
I killed a bull once, but never a man.
A man's easier,
(hushed) Are you one of them -- the Zealots?
Don't be afraid. We're fighting for freedom. The day will come when you ¢an join us, Do you have a knife?
Yes.
Carry it all the time. These are hard times. Judas opens his shirt revealing a double-edged dagger. (CONTINUED)
(continuing) . Yesterday the brotherhood condemned the traitor. The lot fell to me.
The cross-maker?
(nods) Keep your mouth shut. Think about what I've said. The day will come when we will need you.
How will I know? Judas turns. to leave:
Don't be in a hurry. You're not one of the brothers yet. cur TO:
Jesus passes two PEASANT GIRLS reaping in an open field. Their partially open dresses reveal their sweaty breasts. As Jesus averts his eyes, one of the girls calls to him:
Hungry?
(gesturing) There's water and bread in the house. (as Jesus declines) We keep a loaf for travelers. We call it the grasshopper's bread. The First Girl points to a distant village:
But if you want love, go to Magdala. Both Girls giggle. Their sexuality frightens Jesus:
No, I must keep going. Jesus walks quickly away. The Girls turn to each other and laugh again.  10 11 11.
walks along the seashore. Hearing FOOTSTEPS, he stops abruptly. Turns and looks:
Who's that? Who's following me? Seeing nothing. Jesus starts again. The FOOTSTEPS return -- LOUDER.
Is that you? He clutches his head, collapses to his knees in pain:
Magdalene! Magdalene!

Jesus walks through the narrow streets of Magdala a fish- market village on the Sea of Gennesaret, which also serve as a rest spot for caravaps and traders en route from the Indias to Tyre and Sidon. The streets are crowded with camels, donkeys and traders of all descriptions: Mongols on horseback, Afghans laden with rugs and blankets, Nubian slaves following their Greek and Roman masters. Jesus pushes his way through a crowd as he reaches the home of Mary Magdalene. A row of camels, horses and donkeys stand outside. Jesus enters. As Jesus enters, A NAZARENE calls to him:
Ah, Carpenter, you've come to worship? The man laughs and moves on. curt TO:

A camel sleeps by the well in the center of the courtyard Jesus latches the door behind him. A dozen traders and merchants are seated on benches aroun the courtyard; each waits his turn with the Magdalene. (CONTINUED)

They have come from the four corners of the earth. Side by side sit a Bedouin in a long white jellab, a young Indian nobleman with gold bands around his ankles, a fat green-turbaned TURK. The hot sun beats down on them all. Each sweats, looks impatiently from side to side, engages in small talk. How much are slaves selling for in Alexandria and Damascus? What is the trading price of cinnamon and pepper? A short Bedouin emerges from Magdalene's house. He passes through the courtyard without glancing to either side. The next in line, an old Jew, enters Magdelene's door. Th Turk calls to him:
Hurry up, old man. Don't take all day! The others join in laughter.
is waning. Three merchants wait with Jesus. An old woman passes through selling bread, dates and wine. An Egyptian emerges from the Magdalene's house. Another man gets up. Jesus defers to him.
Jesus sits alone. The last customer closes the courtyard or. Jesus stands, enters Magdalene's house. curt TO:
Jesus steps into the dark, amber-lit room. Mary, lies naked on a stack of blankets, covered with the sweat of all nations. Facing the wall, she calls out in a hoarse voice:
Is there anyone else? Jesus stops in the middle of the room, wable to go further. (CONTINUED)
Mary turns and recognizes Jesus. She instinctively pulls the blanket over her nakedness.
What are you doing here?
I want you to forgive me. The Magdalene doesn't understand.
I've done a lot of wrong things. I'm going to the desert to be cleansed. The worst things I've done are to you. Forgive me,
Ah, now I get it. You sit out there all day with the 'customers'. Then you come in here with your head down. La-te-ta. It ain't that easy. I ain't gonna forgive you just ‘cause you wanna be forgiven,
(falls to his knees) It's my fault, but I'll pay the debt.

You bleat like an animal. Lift your head up and face the truth. You want the same as the others. But you can't admit it, so you blame me. I pity you, Jesus. 1 detest you. Jesus, his head bowed low, starts to weep:
You're full of the devil. Please, can’t you see that? Tears fall from Jesus' cheeks. Magdalene sits up, puts her arm on his shoulder:
Don't you understand? A woman is like a wounded doe. All she can do is lick her wounds. That is her only joy. (CONTINUED)
(looks at her) Don't you remember when we were children? Mary's eyes are also wet:
Yes, I remember. I pity you. I detest you. Every time I see you wy heart breaks. (starts to get up) Look the other way. I'm naked. Mary stands and puts a dress on. CUT TO:
Mary takes a casserole from the fire, pours it into a bow and hands it to Jesus with a barley roll. Jesus, starved, bites into the bread:
Is that the way you eat? Without saying grace? Don't you think you oughta thank God for giving you bread, beans and whores? The bread sticks in Jesus' throat:
Why do you hate me? Why do you tease me? Let bygones be bygones. Forgive me.
Stop whining. Forgiveness isn't given, it's taken. Jesus eats. Mary looks at him tenderly. She touches his ace.

Yes, I remember when we were children. When you were three and I was one. (Jesus does not respond) I remember when we laid under the tree together. There were three steps leading to your house. I'd watch you trying to climb. I wanted to help you but... (CONTINUED)
Magdalene is coming on to him. He is her one, her only, h lifetime love. No matter what he does, she eB hever stop” loving him. Jesus is afraid; he knows her power -- and his weakness.
Stop! He stands and walks over to the fire.
I never felt so much tenderness toward anyone as felt for you then...
. (his head in his hands) Adoriai! God, help me! (to Magdalene) I'm thinking about God. I must leave... His voice is strangled, heartbroken.
Please stay. That is, if you will condescend to share a prostitute's shabby room. “" (Jesus doesn't respond) It's cold. Sleep by the fire. Jesus walks to the door:
I can't stay.
‘Don't worry. I won't tempt you. I won't touch your precious virginity.
I'm sorry. Jesus leaves. The door rattles against the jamb. A moment after he exits, Mary Magdalene sinks her head into the blankets, sobbing.
Jesus walks hurriedly toward a walled desert commme. The landscape is now barren, and wild. In the distance, sheer cliffs ascend from a sandy plain. (CONTINUED)

In Christian times, these communes were called monasterie but these pre-Christian gutposts lacked the doctrinal sim and ascetic commitment of the later Catholic monasteries. They were simply groups of religious men living together meditate, do good works and preserve the Torah and other religious documents. Jesus knocks on the main door. He waits anxiously as the ABBOT? opens the door.
Thank God. I thought I’d never make it. Please let me in. I'm safe now. The Abbot, taken back, lets Jesus in. cuT TO:
-- Jesus, now bearded, copies scrolls with other acolytes -- Jesus works the commune garden.

Jesus: sleeps on a woven mat. He hears a HISSING SOUND. His eyes open, he sits up. A snake emerges from a hole in the wall and slithers acro the earthen floor. Another snake follows it. The snakes coil around each other and copulate. Jesus sits up, his back to the wall, watching:

Why now after all this time? So this is sex. Men and women coupling. This is why they were thrown out of Paradise. (watches the snakes) But everything is of God. And everything has two negpings, one obvious, one hidden. What are they telling me? He looks at one of the snakes. It speaks to him in Mary Magdalene's voice: : (CONTINUED)

Jesus, I forgive you. The snakes change color as they coil. Is this real -- ora vision? The question doesn't occur to Jesus. Nor would it to his contemporaries. They lived in a time which accepte healings, miracles, stigmata and visions as extensions of the natural world. Jesus grabs his chest; the snakes hiss inside his breast.
Leave me alone. Jesus breathes a sigh of relief. The Abbot stands in the door, Jesus looks up. The snakes are gone.
What's wrong? Jesus doesn't answer, The Abbot puts his fingers to Jesus lips.
They're gone.
Yes, they've fled.
Where?
And now you must leave too.
What?
The snakes came from you. Now you must leave too. Go into the villages. Stand and speak.
To who?
To anyone who will listen.
And say what? (CONTINUED)
Don't worry about that. Just open your mouth. Do you love mankind?
I see men and I feel sorry for them, nothing else.
That's enough. It’s time for you to leave, .
That's why I was sent here?
I don *t know. cur TO:
A full moon illuminates the walled enclave.

A palm-sized lamp burns as Jesus straightens his room. Hi few possessions are neatly laid out for travel. He hears a HISSING NOISE outside the room. Stops. Listens He cautiously opens the door and steps into the corridor.
Jesus strains to see:
Hello? Suddenly an arm grabs Jesus from behind and throws him against the wall. Judas stands in front of him, panting, his double-edged dagger in his hand. His red face glistens with anger.
Crucifier! (CONTINUED )
Judas? Is that you?
Welcome. I've come to kill you. I hissed and you came. Judas pushes Jesus inside the cell.
Judas locks the door behind him. He throws the ‘elbow key across the room.
Did you hear me? Don't start crying. Get ready. Jesus, composed, stands across the room.
I am ready.
Don't make any noise. Don't call for help.

I'm happy to see you, Judas, It wasn't you that hissed, It was God, Can't you see? This is perfect, Tonight, I was cleansed. I'm tired of wrestling with God; I'm tired of living. (opens his tunic) Here's my neck. Cut it with your knife. Judas backs off. He is disgusted by the sight of Jesus’ bare neck, He has come here to fig t like a man, To spill blood in a struggle. He puts his dagger to Jesus’ neck:
Why don't you resist? What kind of man are you? Fight!
(calm) Why? What you want, I want -- and God must want it too, because that's why he brought us together. (CONTINUED)
(takes his knife down) I put a knife to your neck and you don't blink. What's going on?
Think whatever you want,

(studies him a second) ~ Okay. You may think I'm just a stupid blacksmith. But you talk -- I'll understand. Who are you? What do you want? What are all these stories which follow you; a flowering staff, a Lightning flash, the voices you hear, the fainting spells which seize you? What's your secret?
Pity.
Pity for who? Yourself? For Israel? Is that it? Are you tortured by Israel's suffering?
Pity for man.
Man! The Greeks who slaughtered us -- they were men, weren't they? And the Romans -- they're men, too. Don't pity man, pity Israel. The rest can go to Hell.
I feel pity for donkeys, sparrows...
And ants? I suppose you feel pity for them, too?
Yes. Everything's a part of God. When I look into the ant, into his shiny black eye, I see God. (CONTINUED)
You don't fear death?
Why should I? Death isn't a door which closes; it's a door which opens. It opens and you enter. Judas, confused, lowers his knife:
If I don't kill you, what will you do?
I don't know. LI want to speak to others,
What are you going to say?
(shrugs) I'll just open my mouth and God will do the talking. Judas wavers between confusion and anger. He looks at Jes he sees a GLOW behind his head. He no longer has any tast for this task.
What are you waiting for Judas?
Who are you? Maybe you're the one who will make the people rise up against the Romans. Maybe you're the one we've been waiting for.
Maybe God didn't send you to kill me. Maybe he sent you here to follow me. I am ready to be killed: I'm also ready to live. Decide. Judas is in a quandry:
Don't be in such a rush. It's a long night. (pause) You're a strange one, (MORE) (CONTINUED)

I'll tell you what I’m going to do. I'm going to sleep down here by the door and think about it, You turn your head away from me. I need more time to think, Jesus lies on his mat, his face to the wall. Judas sits, his back to the door, thinking. He puts his knife away.

Judas and Jesus walk across the plain toward Magdala. A wind blows across the Sea of Gennesaret. On the hillside, the flowers -- red anemones and white narcissus -- are in bloom. . Jesus, bearded, is dressed in monastery whites. For the first time he looks like familiar Jesus of romantic paint ings. The meager possessions are wrapped in cloth. Judas and Jesus appear to home come to an understanding.
Zebedee, James, John, Philip and two others approach the house. Two camels, their hampers packed, are tied outside The buildings are constructed of wood and black basalt ro

(points to camel) Can you believe this? It's bad enough we live in a whorehouse, but she, a Jew, works on Sabbath, While our women can't even look in a mirror, she makes ‘love' with Romans. Zebedee's voice is raised. A crowd starts to gather. TABA a Zealot and trouble-maher, joins with two companions.
Yeah, we come back from synagogue and and lock the other way. A WOMAN stands across the narrow street:
You ought to see the things I see. I'm too poor to move, so I have to put up with it.  24 25 23.
You shouldn't move.
The whore should move.
Let's put an end to it. Tabas and his companions bang on Magdalene's door. The growing crowds egg them on. cut TO:
Jesus and Judas enter the village. The streets are quiet. It is Sabbath. Ahead, they hear a commotion.
What is it?

Let's find out. They hurry through the streets until they come to a clear A mob has assembled around a shallow pit. Judas, the man of action, pushes his way through the crow Jesus .follows. Mary Magdalene lies in the pit, her knees and elbows are bloody from being dragged down the street. Terrified. The crowd, in a festive mood, hurl insults and spit at he Children collect rocks for a stoning.
(to Judas; urgent) It's Magdalene. Jesus steps into the center of the pit, stands next to Magdalene and holds up his hands:

Stop! First there's a stunned silence, then a buzz runs through the crowd. No one is more surprised than Judas. He watche closely. In the crowd Philip and Peter have joined Andrew and John Tabas calls out: (CONTINUED)
Get out of the way. She violated the Sabbath. She must pay the price. A small anonymous stone hits Magdalene's hip. She grabs Jesus' leg.
Help!
(chants) Death! Death! Death! Jesus walks in a circle around Magdalene. He stares her accusors in the eye.
Listen to me! Look me in the face. Which of you has not stolen, lied, murdered? Let the one without sin throw the first stone. The crowd is frozen, Zebedee picks up a large rock.
I'm not afraid. I'm innocent.

(steps up to him) Don't make a mistake, Zebedee. There is a God. Don't tell me you've never cheated an employee, snuck into a widow's bedroom at night? Aren't you afraid God will paralyze you if you lift that stone? at your hand will wither and hang at your side? . The old man is suddenly filled with fear and superstition Zebedee drops the rock and runs. The sympathies of the mo shift to Jesus. Judas is heartened. Perhaps this is the leader to unite the people. Tabas and his companions start toward Jesus, but Judas st between them, braced for action. The crowd, afraid of Jud backs away. Jesus helps Mary to her feet. Judas calls to the crowd: (CONTINUED)
Come, follow the rabbi.“ He will speak, Judas, Jesus and Magdalene walk away from the pit toward outskirts of town. A large segment of the crowd follows. One VILLAGER whispers to another:
What's happening? Is Magdalene getting married? cut To:

Jesus and Judas lead the curious crowd up a steep, green hillside. In the distance the sun is low over Mt. Hebron. Magdalene sits near Jesus' feet; Judas stands in the back ground. The crowd waits to hear what Jesus has to say. Jesus looks out over the racamuffin villagers, the peacef countryside:
This is the moment I've always feared. There is so much to say. God has so many miracles. A pause. The words burst out:

Brothers! I'm glad to see you. Let me tell you a story. A man, a sower, was sowing in his field. One seed fell on the road -- the brids ate it. Another fell on stones and died. But another took root, sprouted, became grain and fed many people. (pause) Don't you have ears? Do you hear me?
(beligerent) I got ears, but I don't understand. Be clearer. Jesus thinks, then says softly:
I am the sower. (CONTINUED)
God help us! I suppose we're the stones? A moment of confusion. Zebedee says to those near him:
Another beggar. John, an open-faced, fuzzy-cheeked boy about 19, leaves h father and approaches Jesus:
Rabbi, tell me. If you are the sower and we are the stones, what is the seed? Jesus is baffled; he has no answer. John repeats the question:
What is the seed you offer? The answer comes to Jesus:
Love one another. Love one another! The crowd whispers: "What did he say?" "Love each other?"
That's stupid. We're starving. Tortured. Hungry. How can hungry people love each other?
(steps forward) Yes, 'Rabbi,' is this what I've been waiting for? Love one another? T suppose that means love the Romans too
I used to think God was angry, but not any more. He used to jump on my head like a crazy bird with claws. But then he came to me like 2 cool breeze and said, ‘arise’ -- and here I am.
Go to hell! (CONTINUED)
Pie in the sky. Jesus, speaking rapidly, goes directly to the social conc of the mob:

Blessed are those who hunger and thirst after righteousness, for their stomachs will be filled with bread. Blessed are those who mourn, for God will comfort them. Blessed are the meek, the suffering, for God will give them a kingdom in heaven. Jesus is now talking like a prophet -- a Zealot. The dirt-poor villagers are agitated: "Yes, we will get t wealth of the rich; we'll get Israel back."
Let's kill the rich!
Why bother with the rich? Kill the Romans!
(protests) I didn't say death. I said love! The crowd, incited by rhetoric and hunger, disperses in search of shops to plunder.
(motions to his son) Come on, let's get out of here.
No. Go on without me. John and Andrew stay behind with Peter, Philip and Judas. Jesus wipes Mary Magdalene's bloody feet with his tunic.
Rabbi. I'll come with you. You need someone to cook and...
No. Go back home and be an example. He helps her to her feet, kisses her forehead.

Another day. Jesus leads his little band along the seasho Peter, John and Andrew walk with Jesus; Judas and Philip follow. Two peasant women, a street urchin and a couple o doszs bring up the rear. They approach Zebedee who mends his nets with James, Nathaniel and two other fishermen.
Hello Zebedee.
(to John) Where have you been? We've been working all morning. John steps over to his brother:
Come with us. Believe me -- this is for real. Just what we talked about.
(joining in) You don't have to work for your old man anymore.
